title: Vaccine Recommendations
text:
Calves should receive at minimum a 5 Way Respiratory vaccine and 7 Way Clostridial vaccine 2 times between 30 days of age and weaning.

title: Cattle Heat Stress Resources
text:
K-State Mesonet Animal Comfort Index - this tool uses temperature, humidity, and wind speed to calculate an animal comfort index. Cattle on pasture with plenty of water generally do not need special attention, but cattle in a lot might, and especially fat cattle in a lot. Make sure you have a plan for providing extra water if the animal comfort index is in the orange or red. Consider providing extra water when index is yellow if times of orange or red are predicted following the yellow time.

Heat Stress 
Water Requirements

title: AST Interpreter
text:
Warning



This tool is still under development.

Horn Flies

Identification:

Congregate along the back and sides of cattle
Small (3-5mm)
Bloodfeeders

Prevention and Control:

Ear-tags should be used once 100-200 flies per cow are present to help avoid resistance and should be removed in the fall
Pour-ons such as ivermectin can be used but are only effective about 28 days so reapplication is necessary
Back rubbers and dust bags can be effective when hung in locations cattle can self treat and don’t require handling of cattle
Oral larvicides can be beneficial mixed in feed or mineral but only protect against more larvae, not from adult flies




Face Flies

Identification:

Dark gray in color
6-8 mm in size
Non-biting, but contribute to pink eye
Congregate around wounds as well as ocular and nasal discharge

Prevention and Control:

Pyrethroid ear tags
Pour-ons
Back rubbers and dust bags can be effective when hung in locations cattle can self treat and don’t require handling of cattle
Control can be more difficult as these flies spend fewer moments on the cattle




Stable Flies

Identification:

Gray with checkerboard pattern
7-8 mm in size
Bloodfeeders
Congregate on legs
Present mid-May through September

Prevention and Control:

Sanitation is most effective, removing locations for larvae to develop such as manure piles
Measures should be taken when even 5 flies per head are present
Tend to rest in shaded areas and premise spraying can create some relief

title: Research
text:
LVR participates in multiple research projects aimed at improving livestock health, and has a special interest in antimicrobial stewardship.  We are passionate about improving our ability to fully evaluate the effects of treatments we recommend for livestock systems.    
For more detailed information about research activities please contact us by phone (620-755-3500) or email (livestockvets@gmail.com).

title: Calving
text:
Stage 1
Animal is restless, may get up and down, abdominal contractions present
Duration: 1–12 hours
⇩
Stage 2
Water bag out or animal is laying down pushing
Duration:

1–2 hours (cow)
1–4 hours (heifer)

⇩
Calf Delivered

Cow should make progress every 30 minutes.
If you come back 30 min later and everything looks the same, you likely have a problem.

Dummy Calves





Image Source

title: Livestock Veterinary Resources
text:
Clinical Veterinary Services: LVR partners with clients to improve herd health by providing production data analytics and mobile large animal clinical veterinary services to select clients near Olsburg, KS.   
Research: LVR participates in contract research projects which improve livestock health by supporting policy change and product development.

title: About
text:
Dr. Nora Schrag
Nora Schrag received her DVM from Kansas State University in 2006, and then spent her first year of practice in the Chaco region of Paraguay.  For the next 6 years she enjoyed rural mixed animal practice in southeast Nebraska.  She then returned to Kansas State College of Veterinary Medicine to teach livestock field services.  This position eventually transitioned into doing research, a PhD, and board certification in clinical pharmacology (Dip. ACVCP).  Nora enjoys the challenge of applying research within the real world of clinical practice.  Her time is split between practice in the flint hills of Kansas and doing data analytics for a variety of veterinary related projects.
 Kristen Smith
Kristen graduated with a Masters in Veterinary Clinical Sciences from Kansas State University in 2022. She completed her bachelors in Animal Science at Kansas State University in 2020, she spent 3 years during undergrad working at the Beef Cattle Research Center as well as a summer at the Dairy. She grew up with horses and now manages a horse boarding facility in Randolph, KS. Kristen is passionate about improving animal health and welfare through data analysis and evidence-based practices. She proudly holds the title of “Sidekick” to Dr. Schrag, and is excited to be a part of the Livestock Vet Resource team.

title: Feedlot Reporting
text:
Graphics and summaries from report files downloaded from your Microbeef Accu-Trac software, if your file size is large you may need to be patient while the page loads.  Although you upload a file to the generator, it doesn’t store that file. So, if you wish to reproduce a report you need to keep your original file to upload again. Or just screen shot the report when you generate it.  If you have questions about how to use this report generator please text Dr. Nora at 620-755-3500
